Kamal Ahmed wrote:
> Joe,
> 
> Thank you for the detailed recipe, I also have started reading your book
> "Junit Recipes", The method activateOptions() does nothing, here is how:
> 
> The test class = WmLoggerFilterTest extends TestCase {}
> testMethod (to be implemented) = testactivateOptions(String name) {// to be
> implemented}
> 
> Parent Class = WmLoggerFilter extends Filter {}
> Method = activateOptions() { super.activateOptions(); }
> 
> Parent Class of WmLoggerFilter = Filter implements OptionHandler {}
> Method = public void activateOptions() {}
> 
> Forgive me, but I am still confused, regarding the steps you have suggested,
> and I just want to understand them better,and I really appreciate your help
> and guidance.
> 
> 1. Write tests for Superclass.activateOptions(), as normal
> - This means that I write test cases for the Filter() Class, Right ? but
> since the method does not do anything, what tests would I write.
> 
> 2.  Everywhere in the tests you create an instance of Superclass, extract
> to a method called create().
> - How would I extract , and there is no create() method in Filter() class.
> 
> In the meantime, I would follow the steps that you have written, and I think
> I am beginning to understand them better.

Read the recipe about "Abstract Test Case", somewhere in the first few 
chapters. It should be able to explain the idea more completely to you.

By the way, if WmLoggerFilter.activateOptions() only invokes 
super.activateOptions(), then why declare the method at all? Not 
declaring it is the same as implementing it as you have done.

Good luck.
